entry.title: Re: Change profit center hierarchy in group reporting's a...
entry.content:
Hi Tess,
As you explain you have quite number of SAP analysis reports. To efficiently update SAP analysis reports with the new profit center hierarchy, the best approach is to use the ‚ÄúManage Global Hierarchies‚Äù app and recreate or copy reports using the updated hierarchy.

Please find below the best option from best practices.

The Efficient Ways to Update Profit Center Hierarchies are mentioned below.

1. Use the ‚ÄúManage Global Hierarchies‚Äù Fiori App
This app allows you to edit and restructure profit center hierarchies centrally.
Changes made here will reflect in new reports and any apps that dynamically pull from the global hierarchy.
However, existing reports may not auto-update unless they are configured to reference the hierarchy dynamically.

2. Copy Existing Reports and Reassign Hierarchy
Since new reports show the updated hierarchy, copying existing reports and assigning the new hierarchy is a practical workaround.
This ensures that the structure is preserved while aligning with the new hierarchy.
Depending on your SAP version and reporting tool (e.g., SAC, Fiori, BW), you may use:
‚ÄúSave As‚Äù or ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù functionality in the report designer
Adjust the data source or hierarchy reference during copy

3. Mass Update via API or Backend Tools
SAP provides APIs and backend tools to update profit center assignments in bulk.
For example, using the Profit Center Group and Hierarchy API, you can asynchronously update hierarchy nodes.
This is ideal for large-scale changes but may require coordination with your SAP technical team.

I will recommend auditing your existing reports to identify which ones are hardcoded to the old hierarchy.
Use the ‚ÄúManage Global Hierarchies‚Äù app to ensure the new hierarchy is properly structured and published.
Recreate or copy reports that don‚Äôt reflect the new hierarchy and ensure they reference the updated structure.
If you have many reports, consider automating the update using SAP APIs or scripting tools.

Best Regards

entry.title: Re: Implementing Crossboarding - any advice?
entry.content:
We recently implemented the latest vers of Onboarding and our vers of Crossboarding differed from the prof svc consulting group and SAP's definition of Xboarding. Our xboarding entails internal hires via RMK AND additional promos etc outside of requisitions (level up promos, etc). This cost a lot of time and $ to clarify the change to the orig definition. Our prior Xboarding involved integrations for RH and cross enterprise xfer identification variables. So we had mult layers to contend with. Areas to be very aware of include business rules attributed to compensatory and pos related personnel transactions, immediate timing sends/record application of impacted emp records to external/integrated Payroll systems upon Xboarding/ONB initiation vs eff date, etc. For SOx compliance, Payroll data, and transaction bus rule needs - while we are still  working out additional kinks for Xboarding triggered ONB standard notifications and the like - my best recommendation is to ensure that your HR users and IT teams are well versed in ALL areas within your system from ONB, RCM, and Platform as well as externally impacted integrated systems (IT accts, Payroll, 401k/Benefits, etc) before mapping out needs and show your prof svc vendors how you currently use your sys, what you need or intend to get, and ensure they can support. 

Best of luck! ONB was a challenge, we had a great consulting group that we worked with and a fantastically creative and innovative prof svc consultant who brought huge lifts to life for our ONB/Xboarding conversion.

entry.title: Difference between posting time and entry time for asynchronous APIs
entry.content:
When making postings with asynchronous APIs, I see the posting is successful, but sometimes the posting time is more than an hour after the entry time. 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Difference between posting time and entry time for as...
entry.content:
Delays such as these are expected behaviour when dealing with asynchronous APIs in S/4HANA Public Cloud. When a CSV file or external system triggers postings, the system first accepts the inbound request, places it in an internal processing queue, and then executes the posting in the background.

This asynchronous mechanism ensures reliability and data consistency when large volumes of postings are submitted, or when multiple transactions involve the same company code or asset that may temporarily be locked by other processes. It also prevents system contention and improves throughput for mass postings.

As a result, some journal entries may appear with a time delay even though no errors are displayed in the monitoring apps. The initial HTTP or upload confirmation only indicates that the request was successfully received, not that the journal entry has already been posted.

entry.title: What's New in SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
SAP Logistics Management is designed to bring warehousing and transportation management into a single, integrated solution.  This streamlines operations and enhances collaboration across your network.

As mentioned in the previous What's New article, we're committed to delivering innovation continuously. This way, you can take advantage of new capabilities as soon as they're ready.

Today‚Äôs update introduces a powerful enhancement to one of our key apps: Define Processing Rules.

 

Define Processing Rules ‚Äì Your Automation Engine

The Define Processing Rules app simplifies business process automation. It helps you create, adjust, and manage rule sets that guide decisions in your logistics processes. By defining conditions and outputs, you reduce manual steps, minimize errors, and save time.

If you've used SAP Business Rule Framework plus (BRFplus) before, you'll be familiar with rule-based automation. Unlike generic business rules engines, the Define Processing Rules app is designed specifically for logistics processes. These include carrier determination, freight tendering template selection, and label format determination. You get predefined templates and parameters that make configuration faster and easier.

 

What‚Äôs New: Test the Rule Definitions

Until now, defining rules involves deploying them and hoping they work as intended. With this release, that changes:

The new testing feature lets you validate your rules . You can test the rule definitions with sample data to confirm whether the logic is correct or needs adjustment.

The process is as simple as that: Choose your rule set, enter sample input data, and review the simulated output. This approach provides a safe space for you to fine-tune logic and avoid costly mistakes.

Test Rule Definitions

What improvements in your automation strategy would you expect from being able to test your rule definitions?
Feel free to share your thoughts and experiences in the comments section below.

For more details, check out the SAP Help Portal and stay tuned for more updates in SAP Logistics Management.

 

Further Information

SAP Logistics Management | Product Page

SAP Logistics Management | Business Process Automation 

SAP Logistics Management | Learning Session

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud UM‚Äôs Event Log Archive and Deletion using SAP Job Scheduling Service
entry.content:
Hey everyone, Inspired by the job scheduler blogpost, Maximizing BTP Job Scheduling Service with SAP PAPM Cloud Universal Model, I‚Äôd like to share with you one topic which can help administrators in archiving and deleting Event Logs from your tenants in a periodic way.

As a ballpark number coming from four (4) different tenants, a logged event ranges between 150-350 bytes per record depending on trace information. This would mean that when there are about 4 million entries it equates to more or less 1GB of memory consumption.

 

If you are interested in trying it on your tenant, below is an example sql syntax.

SELECT SCHEMA_NAME, TABLE_NAME, RECORD_COUNT,
  MEMORY_SIZE_IN_MAIN  AS MAIN_BYTES,
  MEMORY_SIZE_IN_DELTA AS DELTA_BYTES,
  MEMORY_SIZE_IN_TOTAL AS TOTAL_BYTES,
  ROUND(MEMORY_SIZE_IN_MAIN  / POWER(1024, 3), 5) AS MAIN_GB,
  ROUND(MEMORY_SIZE_IN_DELTA / POWER(1024, 3), 5) AS DELTA_GB,
  ROUND(MEMORY_SIZE_IN_TOTAL / POWER(1024, 3), 5) AS TOTAL_GB,
  MEMORY_SIZE_IN_TOTAL / RECORD_COUNT AS BYTES_PER_RECORD,
  ROUND(MEMORY_SIZE_IN_TOTAL/ RECORD_COUNT / POWER(1024, 3), 8) AS GB_PER_RECORD
FROM SYS.M_CS_TABLES
WHERE TABLE_NAME = 'SAP_ACE_EVENTLOGS';

Given above information, let‚Äôs go ahead and see how we can utilize UM released API, Archive of Event Logs in combination with SAP Job Scheduler Service (JSS) to perform the event log cleanup.

Prerequisite
You have gone through Phase I - SAP BTP: Application and Instance Subscriptions and Phase II - SAP BTP: Creation of Customized Application of blogpost, Maximizing BTP Job Scheduling Service with SAP PAPM Cloud Universal Model

Procedure
1. Following Phase III - SAP PAPM Cloud UM: Collect API Action URL, Collect Archive Event Log (Action URL) which may come from the system itself by following the dev tools

or use Universal Model - Administration Service > /archive API.

URL will then look like:
<BTP Proxy Application Routes>/ace/<$batch's request url>/<$batch's payload>
https://jobscheduler-papm-proxy.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com /ace/sap/ace/AdministrationService/archive

2. Following Phase IV - SAP JSS: Job Creation, use the generated URL above in order to create the job.


3. Following Phase V - SAP JSS: Job Scheduling, users can a job or several jobs which can be executed in future time. For example, I wanted to delete the logs and create an archive every 5 minutes until end of the year. You can do it by creating a schedule like below:


this will be executed and run logs for the job will have this execution information.

Usage of 5 minutes interval is used only for test purposes but in a real world you may opt to schedule this on a monthly basis or quarterly basis even. You just need to check the proper scheduling value for it. See cron format for more info.

In the end, you will see in the system entry of archived event logs.


In addition, you will also have a cleaner event log list.


That‚Äôs all for now. Hope it helped you make use of another useful API which can be used in a scheduled manner in SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model. Until next time!

entry.title: How do I transfer values between key figures without causing rounding issues?
entry.content:
Dear SAC Community,

We want to transfer values from Key Figure A with 7 decimal places to Key Figure B with 2 decimal places. Copying the data between these key figures leads to rounding errors. The data needs to be copied to Key Figure with 2 dec. places as we have to export the data to table ACDOCP in our S4 System in which the key figures are restricted to two dec. places. How can we transfer the values from key figure A to keyfigure B without getting rounding errors?

In addition, I will give you a more detailed example. In our scenario we want to distribute 5.000 equally with a 50% share to two Order numbers. In our planning story, we enter 5.000 on year 2026 and the value gets automatically allocated to the underlying periods. Here we use Key Figure A with 7 decimal places

 

OrderSumJanFebMarAprMayJunJulAugSepOctNovDec
#5000416,6666667416,66666676667416,6666667416,6666667416,6666667416,6666667416,6666667416,6666667416,6666667416,6666667416,6666667416,6666667

Now we perform the allocation with a 50% per Order nr. The 7 decimals come in handy as we won't face any rounding issues when performing the allocation.

 

OrderSumJanFebMarAprMayJunJulAugSepOctNovDec
Order12500208,315208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335
Order22500208,315208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335208,335

In order to prepare the data for the S4 ACDOCP export, we move the values from key figure A to key figure B via a data action, which results in rounding errors.

OrderSumJanFebMarAprMayJunJulAugSepOctNovDec
Order12.499,94208,31208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33
Order22.499,94208,31208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33208,33

Best regards

Pascal

entry.title: How to CAST a CHAR(12) field to CHAR(10) and use it in a JOIN inside Custom CDS Views S/4H CloudPubl
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I‚Äôm working in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, and I need to create a join between the following fields:

  • I_PurchaseOrderAPI01.PurchaseOrder (type CHAR(10))

  • I_PurchaseOrderAPI01.CorrespncExternalReference (type CHAR(12))

The issue is that the CorrespncExternalReference field contains the Purchase Order number plus two additional characters.
For example:

450000123456 ‚Üí the real PO number is 4500001234

What I need to do is join both fields using only the first 10 characters of CorrespncExternalReference,
like this:

I_PurchaseOrderAPI01.PurchaseOrder = substring(I_PurchaseOrderAPI01.CorrespncExternalReference, 1, 10)

OR MAY

I_PurchaseOrderAPI01.PurchaseOrder = cast(I_PurchaseOrderAPI01.CorrespncExternalReference as ebeln/char10)

I want to achieve this inside a Custom CDS View, because I‚Äôll later consume it in an Analytical Cube and bring both the Supplier and SupplierName for each Purchase Order.

However, I ran into some limitations:

  • In the Custom CDS Views app, I can‚Äôt use string functions like substring() in the join condition.

  • I also can‚Äôt cast a CHAR(12) to CHAR(10) directly.

  • I tried creating a calculated field (CorrespncExternalReferenceTrim) and then using it in the join, but the system doesn‚Äôt allow calculated fields in joins.

  • I also tried creating a CDS view in Eclipse with this annotations:

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Purchase Order'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: [ #CDS_MODELING_DATA_SOURCE, #CDS_MODELING_ASSOCIATION_TARGET ]
//@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities: #CDS_MODELING_ASSOCIATION_TARGET

but it doesn‚Äôt show up as a selectable data source inside Custom CDS Views. Only SAP standard views or those created directly within the app appears.

My questions are:

  1. Is there any way to perform this kind of join (substring or length-based) directly in Custom CDS Views?

  2. If not, what annotations should I add in Eclipse to make a custom CDS view visible as a data source inside Custom CDS Views?

  3. Are there specific restrictions in S/4HANA Cloud (Public Edition) that prevent using developer-created CDS views in Custom CDS Views?

Any example or best practice would be really appreciated üôè

Thanks in advance,

Luka!

entry.title: Re: Missing Authorization S_DEVELOP when Creating Analyti...
entry.content:
Hello @diana_gonzalezcr60 

Thank you for the clarification and for providing the documentation link.

The S_DEVELOP message, when opening the Analytical List Page in Manage KPIs and Reports, is a known misleading check in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. It indicates missing key-user analytics or extensibility privilege, not backend authorisation.

Please do the following:

Ensure you assign both key roles to your user:

  • SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST ‚Äì to create and manage KPIs, reports, and ALPs.
  • SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC ‚Äì to activate and generate the runtime artefacts.
    (Log off and back in after the assignment.)

Create the ALP from the query instead of the KPI app:

  • Go to Custom Analytical Queries, select your query, create application, and activate on the Analytical List Page. This bypasses the outdated S_DEVELOP check in ‚ÄúManage KPIs and Reports.‚Äù

Please confirm that you are with Client 100; content creation and activation are not supported in 080.

  • Ensure your query is analytical, published, and returns data for the default parameters.

Recommended useful SAP References

  • 3515683 - Error "Missing authorisation; authority check for object 'S_DEVELOP' failed" when copying KPI Group
  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Manage KPIs and Reports (Analytics Specialist role and ALP creation process):https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/c00cbf7fe8464663aee830fb6e7eec13.html

Let me know how it goes

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Introducing Application Mass Processing for SAP Agricultural Contract Management on S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
What is the Application process in SAP ACM

Contract application in ACM is the process of linking (i.e., applying) logistics deliveries to one or more commercial trading contracts. Example: one physical delivery (i.e. a truck) can be applied either:

  • To exactly one contract
  • Split the load to multiple contracts (i.e. 60% to contract A and 40% to contract B)
  • Or even split an incoming load among multiple vendors (i.e. 75% of the loaded commodity is owned by vendor A and the remaining quantity by vendor B).

 

Why mass processing?

In the United States alone, approximately 14.9 billion bushels of corn, 4.37 billion bushels of soybeans and 1.9 billion bushels of wheat were produced in 2024. Assuming an average truck size of 900 to 1,100 BU, it means that approx. 15 million truckloads of corn alone were delivered in the US. This massive number is not even considering other commodities, regions or other mode of transports like trains or barges.

Each of these deliveries are typically linked to many corresponding information and system documents like contracts, scale tickets, or invoices.  Currently, many agricultural businesses struggle to efficiently track and manage relationships between these documents across thousands of transactions. This creates bottlenecks in processing, increases error rates, and forces users to spend valuable time on manual data reconciliation instead of focusing on customer service.

The new Application Mass Processing functionality delivered with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00 in SAP Agricultural Contract Management is directly addressing this challenge.

 

An evolution and not just an enhancement

The Application Mass Processing functionality is an evolution of the existing FIORI App ‚ÄúMaintain ACM Applications‚Äù and adds the often-requested ability of processing in mass.  It allows users now to directly perform required Application actions from the initial hit list in mass without the need to navigate into the details of every Application Document.

It was released with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00.

To fully take advantage of the technical capabilities and advancements provided by S/4HANA and to provide the best possible user experience, a new version of the Commodity Pricing Engine (CPE) was released as well. The new version ‚ÄúAdvanced CPE‚Äù is not only a small overhaul with some cosmetic changes, but a complete re-architecture providing massive performance and usability improvements, enabling the ability to perform mass processing at that scale in first place. All ACM customers who upgrade to 2025 FPS00 have the ability to choose between running the new Advanced CPE or the existing legacy CPE solution; however mass processing is only supported when migrating to the Advanced CPE.

Advanced CPE is positively impacting and improving performance also in many other ACM areas like contracts and settlements.  These are, however, not addressed in this blog. Due to the major improvements Advanced CPE brings, it is recommended to be one of the main focus areas for all customers upgrading to 2025 FPS00 (or higher versions).

 

Which features are supported for mass processing?

Following features that were so far only supported for single document processing are now enabled for mass processing as well

  • Mass apply: apply Application Documents in mass to one or multiple contracts.
  • Reverse: reverse the contract assignment or call-off in mass (and later mass apply to a different contract).
  • Create spot contracts: supporting all the ACM spot contract scenarios like spot immediate, spot end-of-day, accumulate to own or just a simple spot.
  • Split Application Documents: ability to split to one or multiple additional vendors
  • Assign or unassign storage programs: assign storage programs in mass and capture required events for correct billing.
  • Navigation: navigate into other related Apps like Document Flow or the spot monitor.

Let‚Äôs have a deeper look into one of the main features as an example: ‚ÄúMass Apply‚Äù

  • A farmer delivers many truckloads of his crops to the buying company over a time period (i.e. week or more/less) without applying it to contracts at the time of physical unload. This could be for several different reasons, like the contract(s) were not fully captured or approved in the system at time of unload, but only with a delay.
  • After the contracts become available, the trader wants to assign all loads to a contract but must split the assignment into two or more contracts as the first contract does not have enough available contractually-agreed quantity.

First select your documents that you want to apply:

Now select the contracts you want to apply to, and which approach should be followed (Allocation, Sequence or Percentage based ‚Äì see below for more details), and choose to allocate to contracts at the contract or at the price fixation level.  Screenshot shows the allocation by sequence.

Afterwards, simply select ‚ÄúApply‚Äù.

The Application process in mass offers the same great functionality and flexibility to apply the AppDocs to contracts as single document processing. End user can manually add required contracts or let the system propose the contracts that are eligible. Assigning the loads / AppDocs to contracts can be based on various approaches:

  • Allocation: end user can allocate manually exactly how much quantity should be allocated to which contract (if multiple contracts are selected) or price fixation.
  • Sequence base: The first contract or price fixation in the sequence will be used until the entire quantity is consumed. The remaining quantity rolls over to the next contract or price fixation (and so on until the full quantity is allocated).
  • Percentage: The total quantity of all selected loads gets assigned to contracts or price fixations by percentage allocation. Example: 60% get assigned to the first contract and 40% to the second contract.

 

Thank you to our partners

A very special thank you to our industry co-engineering consortium partners. Their input was invaluable in building these best-practice processes. Our industry partners not only provided us with constant direct feedback from business users ensuring the right processes were developed with focus on usability that is easy to use for the business, but also supported heavily in testing the solution ensuring a high-quality solution that was tested on hundreds of different business scenarios and variations.  

 

Benefits in a nutshell

  • Increased performance and efficiency to process applications through support of mass processing functions
  • Reduced error rates while minimizing rework and business partner complaints
  • Holistic View of all relevant delivery and contract information in a central place

 

References

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD_PE
  • Product Help - Maintain ACM Applications: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/29b076e23a9f4b0b9d41c5af9c6f7da0/7dfdbcf83bff412998754c9ec09541b0.html
  • What‚Äôs New documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/f5d3e1005efd4e86acf9a65abf428082/5f4c53ef5333471ebac73731de9d0289.html

We have checked all settings as well as the field status of the account. What could be the issue?

entry.title: SLT DIMS Compatibility
entry.content:
Hi Team,

Currently we are on SAP LT Replication Server 3.0(DMIS 2018_1_752 SP06) , The successor for this is SAP Landscape Transformation Replication Server for SAP S/4HANA 1.0(SAP LTRS) with S/4 HANA foundation 2025. So when we upgrade, it will use a new DMIS 2020.

Our Source ECC systems are with version 2011_1_731 SP21 . So would like to check the compatibility, if we upgrade to DMIS 2020 in LT server, do we need to upgrade our DMIS add-on in Source systems as well? or will the current version 2011_1_731 SP21 is still compatible for DMIS 2020 of LT server.

Thanks,


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: SLT DIMS Compatibility
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

 

I'm assuming you would use one of the latest SP version of DMIS 2020. For example DMIS 2020 SP09 or SP10. 

Since DMIS 2020 is equivalent to DMIS 2018, as you can see in note 0002675613 - SLT (DMIS 2010 / DMIS 2011 / DMIS 2018 / DMIS 2020 / DMIS 2025 / S/4HANA) Installation, Corrections and Release Information

Then yes, DMIS 2020 SP09 (equivalent to 0003487355 - Release Information SLT - DMIS 2018 SP13) or DMIS 2020 SP10 (equivalent to 0003657956 - Release Information SLT - DMIS 2018 SP14) are both compatible with source on DMIS 2011 SP21.

 

Best Regards, 

SAP Support

entry.title: A request to Implement a limit on the correction request sum for CR and DR Documents
entry.content:
We need a solution to prevent the creation of correction requests (CR and DR documents) when their total sum exceeds the value of the original invoice.
The system currently does not block such actions, potentially leading to incorrect settlements and financial discrepancies.
Document types affected: CR and DR. 

Expectation: The system should block the creation of correction documents if the total of all corrections exceeds the original invoice amount. 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: A request to Implement a limit on the correction requ...
entry.content:
Try utilising BAdI - SD_SLS_CHECK_ITEM. By reading CDS views using 'PRIVILEGED ACCESS' such as; I_SDDocumentMultiLevelProcFlow to get all other referenced credit memo requests, I_BillingDocumentItem to retrieve the value of the item and I_SalesOrderItem to calculate the value of all the (G2N) items already created against this Invoice. Once you have this you could raise a message once the value is exceeded.

Alternatively, you can raise a feature request asking the Completion Rule for item category G2N to be set to ' Item is completed after full target value is referenced' but consider other customers already use the functionality as it behaves today.

entry.title: Re: Event reason derivation for internal hires
entry.content: Hi Francisco, this is correct. When that switch is enabled, you will not be able to use anymore a rule with context Onboarding = YES, and Internal Hire = YES. You need to create separate rule.

entry.title: Re: why Inbound delivery can't be displayed individually...
entry.content:
• Go to PO item details ‚Üí Confirmations tab. Check the confirmation control key used (e.g., LA, AB, etc.). Ensure it allows multiple confirmations and is set to update MRP. If the confirmation control is not set to update MRP, MD04 will not reflect each confirmation line.
  • Confirm whether the delivery schedule (EKET) has been updated for each confirmation. MD04 reflects EKET delivery dates, not just confirmation lines. If all confirmations are linked to the same EKET line, MD04 will show only one. Solution: Split the PO item into multiple schedule lines (EKET) with distinct delivery dates.
  • Confirm that the confirmations are relevant for MRP. In customizing: SPRO ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Confirmations ‚Üí Set Up Confirmation Control. Ensure the confirmation category (LA) is flagged to update MRP.
  • If LA confirmations are linked to inbound deliveries, check whether those deliveries are created and posted. MD04 may only reflect posted inbound deliveries or delivery schedules, not just confirmations.
  • AB confirmation typically reflects order acknowledgment. If AB notes are showing correctly by delivery date, it means the confirmation data is stored ‚Äî but not necessarily linked to MRP.

Finally, if you want MD04 to show three separate lines, you should:

  • Split the PO item into three schedule lines (EKET) with distinct delivery dates.
  • Ensure each line has its own LA confirmation.
  • Confirm that the confirmation control key updates MRP.
  • Optionally, create inbound deliveries for each confirmation.

entry.title: Optimizing Accessibility for Vision Loss
entry.content:
Globally, an estimated 36 million people are blind[1], and tools like screen readers can help them interact with software. For this community, an inclusive experience isn't simply about moving through content line by line‚Äîit's about being able to navigate efficiently and interact with content that might otherwise be inaccessible. However, designing for accessibility benefits not only people with permanent vision loss. It also helps anyone facing temporary or situational challenges, such as trying to view a screen in bright sunlight or dealing with an eye infection or injury.

A person who is blind stands confidently with their arms crossed and smiling. Text reads: ‚Äú36 Million¬π people worldwide are blind. SAP designs for those who are blind. Check out our tips for reading order, descriptions, live messages and more.‚Äù

Design for Accessibility is Design for Everyone‚ÄØ

When we design with accessibility in mind, we're not just checking a box‚Äîwe're creating digital experiences that are easier to use for everyone. Interfaces that are simple to navigate and content that's easy to find don't just help some users; they make products better across the board.

5 Tips to Optimize Accessibility for Those with Vision Loss‚ÄØ‚ÄØ

Designing with empathy begins with understanding the wide range of vision loss‚Äîfrom permanent to temporary and situational challenges. To help turn this understanding into concrete action, SAP's Accessibility Design Tools, Second Edition, and the Inclusive Research Handbook provide a solid foundation. With these resources, here are five tips to optimize your design for users with vision loss:

‚ÄØ1. Code Order

  • Ensure the underlying code order matches the visual flow of information.
  • Avoid using CSS positioning or layout properties that rearrange content visually without also updating its sequence in the code.‚ÄØ
  • Why?‚ÄØA screen reader processes the code, not the visual display. For users with low vision who can still perceive the layout, a mismatch between what they see and hear can be disorienting and increase cognitive load. This confusion can make simple tasks more prone to errors and difficult for people with low vision and vision loss.‚ÄØ

‚ÄØ2. Heading Hierarchy

  • Structure content using a clear heading hierarchy (<h1>, <h2>, etc.) to create a logical outline.
  • Define the primary regions of your interface‚Äîsuch as the navigation, main content area, and footer‚Äîusing landmark elements.
  • Why? Screen reader users depend on headings and landmarks to understand the layout or quickly move to relevant sections. Without a proper structure, they are forced to listen to all the content, turning a quick search into a long and tedious task. This auditory fatigue makes it difficult to build a mental map of the interface and efficiently navigate to relevant sections.

‚ÄØ3. Unique Accessible Names

  • Every interactive or informative element, such as buttons, links, icons, form fields, and images, needs to have a clear and unique accessible name.
  • For complex elements like charts, add extra descriptions to ensure screen reader users receive the same guidance as those navigating visually.
  • Why?‚ÄØAn element without a clear, accessible name leaves users unaware of its function, leading to confusion and errors. Missing additional descriptions for complex data prevents users from accessing the same key information as users navigating visually. This can make it difficult to understand the content fully.

4. Keyboard Focus Order

  • Ensure the keyboard focus order is logical and that no interactive elements are skipped.
  • Content that updates dynamically (like status messages or search results) should clearly announce these changes to the user without unexpectedly moving their focus.
  • Why?‚ÄØScreen reader users often combine two modes of navigation: tabbing through interactive elements and moving through content line-by-line with arrow keys. This dual-mode navigation breaks down when the focus order is inconsistent or elements are skipped. Users can become disoriented, miss critical information, or get trapped in a component with no keyboard-accessible way out, making the interface feel unreliable and difficult to use.

‚ÄØ5. Repeating Components

  • For repeating components, ensure identical links or buttons have unique accessible names that provide necessary context.
  • Instead of multiple generic labels like "Read More" or "Edit," the accessible name should specify the item it relates to, such as "Read More about Accessibility Services" or "Edit Profile Information."
  • Why?‚ÄØMany screen reader users navigate by selecting a category of elements, such as links, headings, or form controls, to find what they need quickly. However, this method becomes ineffective when the element's labels are generic and identical. The user then has to painstakingly sift through surrounding content to understand each item's context, turning a quick process into an inefficient experience.

How SAP Designs with Accessibility in Mind‚ÄØ

Technology keeps changing, but our commitment to Accessibility remains constant. We're focused on ensuring innovation moves forward without leaving anyone behind. To achieve that goal, we are actively innovating how accessibility considerations can be integrated in all parts of the Product Development Lifecycle, especially in early phases like design.‚ÄØ

Want to dig deeper? Explore SAP's Accessibility Design Tools, Second Edition.

 

References:‚ÄØ 

  1. Lancet Global Health. (2017). Magnitude, temporal trends, and projections of the global prevalence of blindness and distance and near vision impairment: a systematic review and meta-analysis. The Lancet Global Health, 5, 9.‚ÄØ

entry.title: Re: Cancelled work order statuses
entry.content:
Yes you have standard report IW38. Go to IW38, set Selection criteria like Order type, Plant, Date range & System status where enter TECO and execute the report. Click change layout or Cntrl+F8 to add the below fields

You may need to scroll or search in the field list to find these.

entry.title: How to Download Adaptation Project Deployed to S/4HANA On-Premise System
entry.content:
For UI5 Apps and legacy UI5 Extension Projects, the project source is deployed to the UI5 ABAP Repository as a BSP Application, and program /UI5/UI5_REPOSITORY_LOAD can be used to download the source files in a ZIP file (at least those that were included in the deployment).

Adaptation Projects are deployed to the Layered Repository, not the UI5 ABAP Repository, and so the same program cannot be used. Is there an alternative program which can download the adaptation project source from the Layered Repository in a similar way? Is there a way to extract an adaptation project from an S/4HANA On-Premise system using Fiori Tools in BAS or VS Code?

entry.title: Re: How to create a RAP BO to change the content of a customizing table in the production client
entry.content:
@ISReddy 

If you have a customizing transport request, you can use transaction SE09 to manually add a new object to one of the assigned transport tasks: Program ID = R3TR, Object Type = TDAT, Object Name = <The generated Transport Object>.
Then doubleclick on the Object Name and  enter the table name(s) and <client>* as Table Key.

entry.title: Re: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, We can't use the...
entry.content:
Hello @Kimaro 

Good question, you‚Äôre correct to notice the inconsistency.

  • App ID F3476 is Product Allocation Overview (classic version).
  • App ID F3548 is Product Allocation Overview ‚Äì Version 2, the newer Fiori app replacing F3476 in S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition.

About Processing Mode:
In F3548, the Processing Mode field from the classic app has been removed. The new app features a read-only analytical view with a fixed mode (display only). You can view allocation results and consumption but cannot simulate or change processing modes there.

If you need simulation or editable allocation checking, it is now handled in the app via the Product Allocation (PAL) Monitor in the aATP (Advanced Available-to-Promise) worklist, not inside F3548.

 

Useful SAP Documentation

SAP Help Portal ‚Äì :SAP Help-Product Allocation (PAL)

In short ‚Äî F3548 does not have ‚ÄúProcessing Mode‚Äù. It is replaced by analytics-style viewing; processing and simulation are moved to the aATP availability check apps.

Feel free to reach out if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Unable to post the header discount in PO via integration
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

 

We have reviewed your requirement regarding setting header-level discounts when creating Purchase Orders (POs) via API in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Please find the details below:

1. Header-Level Discounts in SAP Cloud

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud supports header-level discounts, but they are implemented as pricing conditions at the header level.

  • Standard delivered pricing procedures and condition types (e.g., AXX001 or PPR0) cannot be modified directly.

2. Required Customization
To enable header-level discounts, the following customization steps are required (as per SAP Note KB0141565 / 0002844597):

  1. Create a custom pricing procedure (e.g., Z10001).

  2. Create a custom discount/charge condition type (e.g., ZZ01).

  3. Create a custom supplementary pricing procedure (e.g., ZXX001) and include the custom discount condition.

  4. Assign the custom pricing procedure to your Purchase Order flow so that it is picked up automatically.

3. References and Documentation

  • CE_PURCHASEORDER_0001 API Reference

  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Pricing Conditions

  • SAP Note KB0141565 ‚Äì Adding supplementary conditions

Next Steps:

  • Implement the custom pricing procedure and condition type as per SAP guidance.

Best Regards

SAP SUPPORT

entry.title: Re: Depreciation expense decreasing the budget loaded in...
entry.content:
Hello @SUSHMADAKE 

Hi Sushma,

You can remove or replace the WBS element in the asset‚Äôs time-dependent data after postings; it only affects future depreciation runs, not past ones.

If the WBS is Closed or Technically Closed, depreciation fails with an error since no postings are allowed. Update the asset‚Äôs account assignment to a cost center before the next run.

When the WBS is assigned only to the AuC, depreciation won't post to the WBS after settlement; it will go to the final asset's cost centre, which is the correct and recommended setup.

SAP Documentation

  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Project Financial Controller Overview
  • SAP Help-Project Control - Enterprise Projects.

Kind regards,
Chuma

entry.title: Automating Onboarding Initiation from Recruiting in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
One of the most anticipated enhancements in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding is the ability to automatically initiate onboarding directly from the Recruiting module, eliminating manual steps and ensuring a seamless transition for new hires.

With this automation, organizations can now reduce recruiter effort, minimize delays, and improve the overall hiring-to-onboarding experience. Let‚Äôs explore how this feature works, its configuration, and the benefits it brings to your onboarding process.

Why Automate Onboarding Initiation?

Traditionally, onboarding initiation in SuccessFactors required recruiters to manually trigger the onboarding process after a candidate accepted the offer. This manual action often caused:

  • Delays in starting pre-boarding activities
  • Missed onboarding initiations
  • Increased administrative workload
  • Risk of data inconsistency between Recruiting and Onboarding

With Automatic Onboarding Initiation, the system handles this process based on predefined rules and conditions, allowing recruiters and HR teams to focus more on engaging with candidates rather than managing system actions.

How It Works

Once configured, SuccessFactors Recruiting automatically triggers onboarding for a candidate when certain conditions are met ‚Äî typically when:

  • The candidate accepts the offer, and
  • The application status moves to a specific status (e.g., ‚ÄúOffer Accepted‚Äù or ‚ÄúReady to Hire‚Äù).

The system then:

  • Validates the candidate data against the Onboarding eligibility rules.
  • Automatically creates the New Hire record in Onboarding, and
  • Sends relevant notifications to onboarding participants (recruiters, hiring managers, or onboarding administrators).

This ensures that the onboarding process begins immediately ‚Äî without requiring manual initiation

Configuration Steps

1. Prerequisites

Before enabling automation, ensure that:

  • The New Applicant Management Experience must be enabled at all times for the Enable Automatic Initiation for Onboarding option to be displayed on the Onboarding Integration Setup page.
  • Recruiting and Onboarding integration is properly configured.
  • All required data fields are mapped between Recruiting and Onboarding.
2. Enable the Feature in Admin Center

Admin Center ‚Üí Onboarding Integration Setup‚Üí Automatically Initiate Onboarding

Here, you can:

- Enable automatic initiation globally or per requisition template.

- Specify which application status should trigger the onboarding initiation.

3. Define Business Rules

As an administrator, you can now select a new option called Enable Automatic Initiation for Onboarding from the Onboarding Integration Setup page and configure the Trigger Automatic Initiation of Onboarding business rule scenario to define the eligibility for onboarding initiation.

This rule is executed as soon as the status of the candidate moves to the Ready to Hire status, specifically after the offer is approved.

4. Assigning Automatic Onboarding Initiation Rule to a Template

You're now ready to go to Admin Center>Manage Rules in Recruiting to associate your newly created rule with a Recruiting template.

For more information, see the Assigning Initiate Onboarding Rule to a Template topic from the Related Information section.

5. Test the Process
  • Create a test requisition and hire a candidate.
  • Move the candidate to the ‚ÄúReady to Hire and Initiate Onboarding‚Äù status.
  • Verify that onboarding is automatically initiated without manual action.

Key Benefits

  • Time Savings: Eliminates the need for manual onboarding initiation, saving recruiters and HR admins hours of work.
  • Improved Candidate Experience: Immediate onboarding initiation enables candidates to receive their welcome email and pre-boarding tasks sooner.
  • Data Accuracy: Reduces human error and ensures all data flows automatically from Recruiting to Onboarding.
  • Process Consistency: Ensures standardized onboarding initiation across all departments and locations. 
  • Better Compliance: Supports audit readiness with clear, automated initiation logs

Conclusion

The Automate Onboarding Initiation feature in SAP SuccessFactors represents a major step toward end-to-end process automation in the employee lifecycle.
By bridging the gap between Recruiting and Onboarding, it delivers faster, smarter, and error-free transitions ‚Äî enhancing both recruiter efficiency and the new hire experience.

If your organization is looking to simplify onboarding while improving process integrity, enabling this feature is a must-have in your upcoming release.
